column1: The empress had lost her costly diadem
column2: and it could not be found. They searched in every direction
column3: but all in vain. Half distracted
column4: for the mishap boded no good to her or her house
column5: the empress redoubled her exertions to regain her precious possession
column6: but without result. As a last resource it was proclaimed in the public streets: "The empress has lost a precious diadem. Whoever restores it within thirty days shall receive a princely reward. But he who delays
column7: and brings it after thirty days
column8: shall lose his head."In those times all nationalities flocked toward Rome; all classes and creeds could be met in its stately halls and crowded thoroughfares. Among the rest was a rabbi
column9: a learned sage from the East
column11: and lived a righteous life in the stir and turmoil of the Western world. It chanced one night as he was strolling up and down
column15: he saw the diadem sparkling at his feet. He seized it quickly
column17: where he guarded it carefully until the thirty days had expired
column18: when he resolved to return it to the owner.
